Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 2fa322280d730a5ef123c8fe749b90ded90cd293
Can we get an example?  I'm not sure I understand what an "identifier" is.

This commit addresses one of the issues raised in
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097

ex:
'''busctl call -j  "xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper"   "/xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper"   "xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper" "GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById" ssiassas "chassis" "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory" 0 1 "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Chassis" "powered_by" 1  "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.PowerSupply"
{
        "type" : "as",
        "data" : [
                [
                        "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply0",
                        "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply1",
                        "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply2",
                        "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply3"
                ]
        ]
}
'''
I updated the commit and the description of the identifier.
can you summarize the issue for me?

GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById and GetAssociatedSubTreeById simplify the process by consolidating multiple mapper calls into a single operation.

To query the list of ports for a specific adapter:

First, we need to obtain the path to the adapterId. This involves using the getSubTree function to retrieve a list of adapters that have the "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.FabricAdapter" interface. We then iterate through this list to check if the adapterId is present and retrieve its path.

Next, we need to find the ports associated with the fabric adapter by establishing a connection. For each valid adapterId, we use the getAssociatedSubTree function to retrieve the endpoints associated with the adapterIdPath/association.

Instead of making multiple mapper calls, we simplify the process by making a single call to GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById or GetAssociatedSubTreeById to retrieve the list of fabric adapter ports for a specific fabric adapter ID.
Done

Here, this identifier would be the leaf name of the dbus path.
So should we refer to this as `Id' (and explain it as 'leaf' of the dbus path).
Done

It doesn't feel right to me to continue in the direction of adding more methods to apply query constraints. I think we need a better solution in the long run. I'm not sure what that is. Maybe it's some kind of graph query language.

I originally thought about this as doing by pattern - e.g. regexp, but for the simplicity and for the typical usage patterns in bmcweb, we have chosen to propose these `byId` (or `byLeaf`).

- What if we propose  like `GetAssociatedSubTreebyByPathPattern()`?

- Or can we have these `byId()` for now and consider the long run solution separately?

- Or perhaps have a mapper function to expose mapper's `associationMaps' and `interfaceMap` by a function so that the caller can deal with them?

- Or should we live with the current multi-level mapper calls in bmcweb for now?

I don't think adding a regex here really addresses my concern. My concern is the proliferation of the query methods, which your regex proposal would still contribute to. My blue-sky suggestion was more of a singular `Query` method, where we pass it a query written in a DSL. To reach for something that appeared relevant in a quick DDG search, something like Cypher/GQL

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_Query_Language

But that's really long-term stuff, if anyone has the motivation for it. I'm not sure what we do about immediate solutions. Maybe we let the proliferation continue?
Let's not block these new APIs in the hopes that someone invents a new mapper query language.
My hope was that the lack of a CR-1 was an indicator that I wasn't blocking it, but I'll mark this thread as resolved to make it clear.
this is a Redfish path, not an object path.  Can you give an object path here instead?
Done
Could you please review these new methods so that we can utilize them in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097. thx

You can already get this information from the GetAssociatedSubTree, correct?  The only thing we're doing is adding additional filtering of this "by id"?  Do we have some example client-side code that this would make life better for?  Can we link to that?

GetAssociatedSubTree takes the input as an associated path (object path + endpoint association) and interface. It returns only the associated paths that have the specified interface.

GetAssociatedSubTree essentially combines the functionalities of GetSubTree (by id) and GetAssociatedSubTree. It first retrieves the object paths for the specified ID, then constructs associated paths, returning only those associated paths that have the specified interface.

Here is the code snippet where we utilize GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097/65..78/redfish-core/lib/fabric_ports.hpp#449

More discussion:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097/65..78/redfish-core/lib/fabric_ports.hpp#b296
Done
This appears contradictory.  The first sentence says "leaf" but then the example sentence shows `ChassisId` which is not a leaf.
Fixed.
Since these are new interfaces, can we make these object_path, which is what the original ones should have been to begin with?
Done
What is an "association interface"?  This isn't clear to me either in name or in the description.

I named it associationInterfaces because it constructs associated paths by combining the object path and association, returning only those paths that have the specified interface. We use two interfaces, and to differentiate them, I chose the name 'associationInterfaces.' However, I am open to changing the name if there is a more intuitive option.
Changed the name  to endpointInterfaces.
Done
What good is having just the paths?

We use the GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById in the getValidFabricAdapterPath:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097/65..78/redfish-core/lib/fabric_ports.hpp#449

But why?  In what cases is only have the path useful?  Don't you still need to know which service hosts the interface?  

(I'm not going to reverse engineer a half-dozen callback chains from bmcweb code.)

Ex:
The dbus call to retrive the power supplies in the system:

busctl get-property xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/powered_by xyz.openbmc_project.Association endpoints

as 4 "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply3" "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply2" "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply1" "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply0"

Steps involved in the dbus call:

1. Retrieve Chassis Path:
   - Obtain the path of the chassis (ID) in the inventory. Locate the chassis object path that implements the "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Chassis" interface, which uniquely identifies the chassis within the system. For example, assume the chassis path is "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis".

2. Construct Associated Path:
   - Construct the associated path by appending the "powered_by" association to the chassis path. This results in the associated path "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/powered_by".

3. Retrieve Associated Endpoints:
   - Retrieve the list of associated endpoints using the constructed associated path. These endpoints represent the various power supplies associated with the chassis.

4. Filter Endpoints by Interface:
   - Filter the list of associated endpoints to include only those paths that implement the "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.PowerSupply" interface. This ensures that only endpoints representing power supplies are included in the result.

We don't need to specify the service name. Each leaf of the path represents a power supply.

Using the GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById to get the list of powersupplies in the system:


busctl call -j  "xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper"   "/xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper" \
"xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper" "GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById" ssiassas "chassis" \
"/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory" 0 1 "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Chassis" "powered_by" \
1  "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.PowerSupply"
{
        "type" : "as",
        "data" : [
                [
                        "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply0",
                        "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply1",
                        "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply2",
                        "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/chassis/motherboard/powersupply3"
                ]
        ]
}
'''
Done
can you put your objmgr code up somewhere even as a WIP so I can see it?
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-objmgr/+/70699

I still cannot understand, from this text, what this interface does.  If users can't understand from the description how do we expect anyone to ever use it except when they are copypasta-ing some other random code without understanding it.
The description has been updated, hope it is better.
Done
But associations are a single interface.  This is another example where I don't understand what this does.  Are you looking for the pointed-at thing to have particular object make up also?
We are looking for the endpoint paths of the identifier that implement the specified interfaces. These interfaces can be one or more, similar to subtree interfaces.
Done

For more clarity, maybe we can use the term as "Leaf" instead of "Id".

- getAssociatedSubTreeByLeaf()
- getAssociatedSubTreePathsByLeaf()

Other than that, I think this seems good.
@Patrick I was wondering if there is any additional information needed to move this commit forward. Thx

I see a need for this at commits like https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097. 
It seems reasonable to me.

Nitpick:
ChassisId/FanId are supposed to be the name of the chassis and fan, respectively? I think 
`/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/{ChassisId}/motherboard/{FanId}`
makes that more clear

Also below too:
the identifiers would be `{FanId}`.

and in GetAssociatedSubTreePathsById. 


Not sure this makes as much sense having "system" be the identifier but would be simpler.
 For example, in the path
                `/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system`, the identifiers would be `system`.

or "chassis" like your commit msg, would simply things.
Done
I'm still kinda confused too. Can you list the exact steps the code will do?

objmgr commit:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-objmgr/+/70699/3/src/handler.cpp#410


1. Get the subtree D-Bus paths that implement the "subtreeInterfaces" and have the path endpoint "id".

2. Create an association path by concatenating the subtree path with "/" and "association":
   associationPath = subtreePath + "/" + "association"

3. Call `getAssociatedSubTree` to get the endpoint paths of an associationPath that implements the "associationInterfaces".
Can you work that into the yaml?
I updated the description.
I hope this commit is approved soon so that we can start to utilize these new mapper functions.
I haven't seen this other places.. Came from a request in the review. Seems okay here.

It looks good.  
I hope to accept this proposal soon unless there is objection.
Is this waiting on something?

This is still really complex.  I don't really like that we're adding more and more random queries to Mapper that could probably have been done on the client side.  Having said that, at least one owner from mapper needs to +1 this to let me know that they're on board with accepting this (which I guess is just Matt Spinler).

every time I look at this I have to spend 5 minutes getting it straight in my head 😊

I'd like to see confirmation from a bmcweb maintainer that a call to this would even be allowed into that repo.

This commit came from a few bmcweb commits. The desire to make a single mapper call. I support https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/72422/


From  https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61097
Ed Tanous
It's VERY likely we need a new mapper call for this two tiered type of lookup.

Myung Bae
Ok, I'll try to make a new mapper method separately from this commit.
Later once we have the new mapper method, we can refactor this part.

Ed Tanous
Cool, please mark this commit WIP while that work happens if you don't intend on doing it right away.
thanks
